Yes, there have been many instances of athletes using the Olympic games to promote political messages or causes. Here are a few notable examples:

1. Tommie Smith and John Carlos: At the 1968 Mexico City Olympics, African American sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos raised their fists on the medal podium during the playing of the American national anthem. This was a protest against racial discrimination in the United States and marked an iconic moment in the history of the civil rights movement.

2. Cathy Freeman: At the 2000 Sydney Olympics, Australian aboriginal sprinter Cathy Freeman carried both the Australian and Aboriginal flags during her victory lap after winning the 400-meter final. This was seen as a symbolic gesture of reconciliation between Indigenous Australians and the rest of the country.

3. Ibtihaj Muhammad: In 2016, American fencer Ibtihaj Muhammad became the first Muslim-American woman to compete in the Olympics, and she wore a hijab during competition as a way of promoting religious and cultural diversity.

4. Allyson Felix and other athletes: In 2019, American sprinter Allyson Felix and other female athletes spoke out against Nike's maternity policy, which was seen as discriminatory towards female athletes who wanted to have children. This led to Nike changing its policy to allow female athletes to receive full pay and bonuses during pregnancy.

These instances show that athletes can use the Olympic games as a platform to promote political messages or causes and push for social change.
